evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Congress established the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) as an independent federal agency, headed by a five-member commission. By statute, the President may remove Commissioners only 'for neglect of duty or malfeasance in office but for no other cause.' 15 U.S.C. § 2053(a).

extracted.value: Congress established the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) as an independent federal agency with statutory restrictions on presidential removal authority, requiring 'neglect of duty or malfeasance in office' for removal (15 U.S.C. § 2053(a))

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Plaintiffs Mary Boyle, Alexander Hoehn-Saric, and Richard Trumka Jr. were nominated by former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and confirmed by the Senate to serve as CPSC Commissioners for terms ending in October 2025, October 2027, and October 2028, respectively.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs Boyle, Hoehn-Saric, and Trumka Jr. were confirmed by Senate to serve as CPSC Commissioners with staggered terms ending October 2025, 2027, and 2028 respectively

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: On May 8, 2025, Plaintiffs Boyle and Trumka received emails from Trent Morse, Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel. The bodies of the emails stated, in their entirety: 'On behalf of President Donald J. Trump, I am writing to inform you that your position on the Consumer Product Safety Commission is terminated effective immediately. Thank you for your service.'

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: On May 9, Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric and his staff arrived at CPSC offices. CPSC security prevented Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric and his staff from going to their offices but allowed them to stay in the lobby.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs received termination notices via email on May 8, 2025 (Boyle and Trumka) and were barred from CPSC offices on May 9, 2025 (Hoehn-Saric) without justification

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: To effectuate Plaintiffs' purported terminations, Defendant Feldman has prevented Plaintiffs from executing their duties as Commissioners, including by barring their access to their offices and agency email accounts, and by terminating personnel who staff Plaintiffs' offices. On information and belief, Defendant Scott Bessent, who serves as Secretary of the Treasury, and Defendant Russell Vought, who serves as Director of the Office of Management and Budget, have deprived or imminently will deprive Plaintiffs of pay and benefits to which they are entitled.

extracted.value: Defendants Feldman, Bessent, and Vought have blocked Plaintiffs' access to offices/email and deprived them of pay/benefits to effectuate unlawful terminations
